facts: The scientific method is a systematic approach to gaining knowledge through observation and experimentation.
Experimental research involves manipulating one variable (independent variable) to determine its effect on another variable (dependent variable).
Correlational research examines relationships between variables without manipulating them.
Longitudinal research involves collecting data from the same subjects over an extended period.
Quantitative methods involve collecting numerical data for statistical analysis.

definitions.definition: The variable that is manipulated by the researcher in an experiment.
The variable that is measured to see if it is affected by the independent variable.
Participants who do not receive the experimental treatment in an experiment.
Participants who receive the experimental treatment in an experiment.
A value that indicates the strength and direction of a relationship between two variables, ranging from -1 to +1.
The process of ensuring participants understand and voluntarily agree to participate in research.

quotes: “It is the scientific method that provides a framework for systematic inquiry.”
keyPoints: The scientific method consists of asking a question, conducting background research, formulating a hypothesis, testing with an experiment, analyzing data, drawing a conclusion, and communicating results.
Different research designs (experimental, correlational, descriptive, longitudinal) serve different purposes in scientific investigation.
Quantitative methods focus on numerical data for statistical analysis, while qualitative methods explore non-numerical data to understand concepts and experiences.
Sampling methods include probability sampling (simple random, stratified, cluster, systematic) and non-probability sampling (convenience, purposive, snowball, quota).
Research ethics emphasize informed consent, confidentiality, avoiding harm, the right to withdraw, and debriefing.
